column1: Adrahil was a Gondorians Prince who lived around  in the land of Dor-en-Ernil.
He descended from the Númenóreans noble house that settled in Belfalas in the Second Age. Because of this
column2: it is assumed he was an ancestor of Imrazôr
column3: Galador and the Princes of Dol Amroth.

column1: When King Ondoher led his army to face the Wainriders who threatened Gondor
column2: Adrahil commanded the armys left wing. The soldiers of the right wing were under the command of the Kings nephew Minohtar
column3: while the centre was commanded by the king himself and his heir Artamir.

column1: Ondohers enterprise came to a devastating end: he was surprised by the Wainriders
column2: and his forces were overwhelmed. Adrahils soldiers
column4: were shielded from the attack and survived it. Ondoher and Artamir had both been killed
column6: sending Adrahil along with both his own command of the Left Wing and those at the rear of the Right Wing who had not yet been engaged.

column1: Adrahil withdrew south into Ithilien to form a defensive line from Cair Andros to the Ephel Dúath. With these forces he was to cover the approaches of Minas Tirith and allow Minohtar to form a rearguard and attempt to stem the advance of the Wainriders. Adrahil should at once message Eärnil II
column2: and inform him of the disaster of the Morannon and of the position of the retreating Northern Army.

column1: Adrahils fate is uncertain; the Wainriders eventually broke through Minohtars more northerly defence
column2: but whether they penetrated to Adrahils position is unknown. If he survived the initial assault
column3: it seems likely that Adrahil would have joined with Eärnil II in his counter-attack
column4: seeing the ultimate defeat of the Wainriders at the Battle of the Camp.
